name: Kepler-301
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-301 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-301 is a star with 0.795 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.9 times its radius. It is located 2395.00 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-301 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-301 b

Kepler-301 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.51 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-301.

The mass of Kepler-301 b is 1.96 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-301 b is 1.35 that of Earth. At 1.96 Earth masses, Kepler-301 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-301 c

Kepler-301 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.42 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-301.

The mass of Kepler-301 c is 1.96 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-301 c is 1.35 that of Earth. At 1.96 Earth masses, Kepler-301 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-301 d

Kepler-301 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.75 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-301.

The mass of Kepler-301 d is 3.68 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-301 d is 1.75 that of Earth. At 3.68 Earth masses, Kepler-301 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-301, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
